thread.title: Alcoa runs away from Kingston
thread.title_full: Alcoa runs away from Kingston - PrepXtra Story

author: Troy Provost-Heron
title: Alcoa runs away from Kingston
text:
KINGSTON â€” Kingston High School senior quarterback Paul Bolden did everything he could to get back the energy that surrounded the pregame senior night celebration.
After Alcoa struck with an 80-yard punt return by Caleb Woody before the Tornadoes took an offensive snap, Bolden knifed through Alcoa's defense for a 34-yard touchdown to pull the Yellow Jackets within one after a missed extra point.
From there, though, No. 1-ranked Alcoa did all the celebrating, holding Kingston without a first down until its second-to-last possession of the game en route to a 42-13 victory Friday.
"Alcoa has a great football team, a great defensive front, and we just happened to hit a couple of gaps we had and got in the end zone early," Kingston coach Brian Pankey said. "But when you play a team like Alcoa, them just being bigger, faster and stronger just takes over.
"I'm glad with the way our kids competed. They came out here and played hard, but hats off to Alcoa."
The victory was Alcoa's eighth straight in the series, dating back to 1989, and it was due in large part to its rushing attack. The Tornadoes rushed for 243 yards.
"I know we had a lot of people touch it and that's who we are right now," Alcoa coach Gary Rankin said. "We're spreading it around pretty good and hopefully we can continue to do that."
One of those runners wasn't Karim Shereef, who didn't dress for the game because of an injury. Shereef's absence was just precautionary, though. Rankin said he could have played if needed.
Bolden, who rushed for 42 yards on eight carries and completed just one pass for one yard, exited the contest in the second half after he took a hit to the head in the second quarter.
"He came to the sideline and I could just tell he was kind of out of it," Pankey said. "So I decided to pull him because he's got some football to play in him and I didn't see the point of putting him back in."
Bolden will get an extra week to recover as Kingston has a bye before it travels to Loudon on Oct. 30. Alcoa will travel to play Red Bank on Friday.
